posts.name: James Goebel
posts.cooked: We upgraded to version 13 on the VH-109 before we attempted to use the two radios on wifi. The roborio works fine on the USB weather cable. The roborio will not connect on an Ethernet direct cable from the roborio Ethernet port to the laptop port, even though the driver station green lamp shows connected. The Wi-Fi will not work with two or one radio setup. The Wi-Fi will also not work on last year’s radio. I reloaded the SD card twice. The robot runs fine on the USB tether. Years ago a software bug turned out to be a problem like this on a radio, but I have not found any known bugs on the list. Both radios were upgraded, one to local and one to ap. I use the Rio port on the robot radio side.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Is your team number set?  Try running the team number setter.

Additionally screenshots of any relevent screens like the roboRIO settings page when teathered, the drivers stations, etc…all are helpful when troubleshooting.

posts.name: James Goebel
posts.cooked: I reloaded the setups again on both radios for the third time, the Access point again, by the Roborio radio vh-109s. I then went to the Roborio imaging tool again, and reapplied the team number again. The team number was already in the RoboRio, proof is on the imaging page before I reloaded the team number. It would also work on the USB cable, proving that the number was in the RoboRio. When I reloaded the team number again,  the radio wifi worked and tested fine. Thanks for your help. It is always appreciated.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
RummelRobotics:

It would also work on the USB cable, proving that the number was in the RoboRio.

Using the USB cable bypasses the team number. It does not prove that the team number was set in the roboRIO

posts.name: Samuel Helton
posts.cooked: i’ve been having a problem just like this as well, the radio connected to the robot won’t communicate with the roborio and the access point radio cannot communicate with the robot radio as both have been set as one type of radio (i change one radio to be the robot radio and the other to be the access point, both get set to either the access point or the robot radio)

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: Can you send a screenshot of the /status page for both radios reachable at http://192.168.69.1/status

posts.name: Samuel Helton
posts.cooked: I figured out the culprit… it was a faulty ethernet cord. The problem on our end has been resolved

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked: There is a dip switch behind a sticker on the back, simply flip the one that is labeled 3 and it should then be able to broadcast a 6ghz WiFi signal. This isn’t clearly stated on their website unfortunately, let me know if you need further help!

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
This is not anyone in this threads issue. Everyone here is having robot radio–>roboRIO connectivity problems.

And you mean 2.4GHz not 6GHz.

6 Runs always. 2.4 is switched.
